summary: A December 30, 2020 letter from the U.S. Department of Justice's Office of International Affairs to an Assistant U.S. Attorney in New York, transmitting a French request for mutual legal assistance. The letter outlines that French authorities are investigating Jeffrey Epstein, his accomplices, and Jean-Luc Brunel, and that a search was executed at Epstein's Paris residence in September 2019. It instructs the AUSA on procedures for executing the request while maintaining confidentiality.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central subject of the French criminal investigation. The document states French authorities are investigating his actions and those of his accomplices, and that they executed a search warrant at his Paris residence in September 2019.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as an accomplice of Jeffrey Epstein and a subject of the French investigation. French authorities requested information related to her.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: Named in the closing of the letter as a subject of the international criminal matter, indicating the French investigation relates to him.

connections.description: The document refers to Maxwell as an accomplice of Epstein, indicating they are subjects of the same French criminal investigation.
The letter concludes by stating the international criminal matter relates to Jean-Luc Brunel, connecting him to the investigation of Epstein.

events.title: Search of Epstein's Paris Residence
events.description: French authorities executed a search warrant at Jeffrey Epstein's residence in Paris, where they obtained evidence and information.

events.title: DOJ Transmits French MLA Request
events.description: The U.S. Department of Justice's Office of International Affairs formally transmits a French mutual legal assistance request to a U.S. Attorney's Office in New York to aid the French investigation into Epstein and associates.

keyFacts: French authorities opened a criminal investigation into the actions of Jeffrey Epstein and his accomplices, including Ghislaine Maxwell.
In September 2019, French authorities executed a search warrant at Jeffrey Epstein's Paris residence, seizing evidence.
The French investigation has identified multiple victims, though some potential charges are barred by France's statute of limitations.
The U.S. is obligated to assist France under the 1998 U.S.-France Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty, as supplemented by a 2004 instrument.
The document reveals the international scope of the Epstein investigation, specifically naming Jean-Luc Brunel as a related subject.
